dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Kraft Heinz, 325.6 million shares, valued at 25.3 billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kraft Heinz, three hundred twenty five point six million shares, valued at twenty five point three billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz Position: 325.6 M shares Market Value: $25.3B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 18.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge chunk of Berkshire's portfolio—28.7 percent, right? Almost a third!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge chunk of Berkshire's portfoliominus twenty eight point seven percent, right? Almost a third!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz Position: 325.6 M shares Market Value: $25.3B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 18.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Wells Fargo is next with 479 million shares, worth 24 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Wells Fargo is next with four hundred seventy nine million shares, worth twenty four billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wells Fargo Position: 479.7 M shares Market Value: $24 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 17.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So those two alone make up nearly half the portfolio's weight. It's pretty concentrated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So those two alone make up nearly half the portfolio's weight. It's pretty concentrated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 1. Kraft Heinz Position: 325.6 M shares Market Value: $25.3B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 18.7% 2. Wells Fargo Position: 479.7 M shares Market Value: $24 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 17.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Coca-Cola's in there too—300 million shares, 20 billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Coca-Cola's in there toominus three hundred million shares, twenty billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Coca-Cola Position: 400 M shares Market Value: $18.1 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 13.4%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Classic Buffett move, sticking with consumer staples like Coke and Procter & Gamble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Classic Buffett move, sticking with consumer staples like Coke and Procter and Gamble.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of P&G, it's further down at 4.3 billion, but still significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of P&G, it's further down at four point three billion, but still significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Procter & Gamble Position: 52.8 M shares Market Value: $4.3 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 3.2%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got IBM with 81 million shares, though that's dropped off since this data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got I B M with eighty one million shares, though that's dropped off since this data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: IBM Position: 81 M shares Market Value: $11.6 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 8.6%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and American Express is another long-term holding—151 million shares.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and American Express is another long-term holdingminus one hundred fifty one million shares.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: American Express Position: 151.6 M shares Market Value: $9 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 6.6%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I always find it interesting how he mixes financials like Wells and AmEx with steady consumer names.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I always find it interesting how he mixes financials like Wells and AmEx with steady consumer names.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wal-Mart's in there too, 56 million shares, but that's changed a lot recently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wal-Mart's in there too, fifty six million shares, but that's changed a lot recently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wal-Mart Position: 56.2 M shares Market Value: $3.8 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 2.8%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Berkshire sold a lot of that off. And then there are smaller positions like DaVita Healthcare.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Berkshire sold a lot of that off. And then there are smaller positions like DaVita Healthcare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Only about 1% of the portfolio, but still over 2.7 billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Only about one percent of the portfolio, but still over two point seven billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: DaVita HealthCare Partners Position: 38.6 M shares Market Value: $2.7 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 2%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which just shows the scale we're talking about—even the "small" holdings are massive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which just shows the scale we're talking about-even the small holdings are massive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's a mix of huge bets and what Buffett might call "inevitables."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's a mix of huge bets and what Buffett might call inevitables.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though you gotta wonder, with some of these, um, like IBM, how the strategy's evolved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though you gotta wonder, with some of these, um, like I B M, how the strategy's evolved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But the core philosophy? Still buying wonderful companies at fair prices.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But the core philosophy? Still buying wonderful companies at fair prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And holding forever, or at least seeming like it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And holding forever, or at least seeming like it.

artist_script:
HostA: Kraft Heinz, 325.6 million shares, valued at 25.3 billion dollars.
HostB: That's a huge chunk of Berkshire's portfolio—28.7 percent, right? Almost a third!
HostA: Yeah, and Wells Fargo is next with 479 million shares, worth 24 billion.
HostB: So those two alone make up nearly half the portfolio's weight. It’s pretty concentrated.
HostA: Coca-Cola’s in there too—300 million shares, 20 billion dollars.
HostB: Classic Buffett move, sticking with consumer staples like Coke and Procter & Gamble.
HostA: Speaking of P&G, it’s further down at 4.3 billion, but still significant.
HostB: And then you've got IBM with 81 million shares, though that’s dropped off since this data.
HostA: Right, and American Express is another long-term holding—151 million shares.
HostB: I always find it interesting how he mixes financials like Wells and AmEx with steady consumer names.
HostA: Wal-Mart’s in there too, 56 million shares, but that’s changed a lot recently.
HostB: Yeah, Berkshire sold a lot of that off. And then there are smaller positions like DaVita Healthcare.
HostA: Only about 1% of the portfolio, but still over 2.7 billion dollars.
HostB: Which just shows the scale we're talking about—even the "small" holdings are massive.
HostA: Exactly. It’s a mix of huge bets and what Buffett might call "inevitables."
HostB: Though you gotta wonder, with some of these, um, like IBM, how the strategy’s evolved.
HostA: For sure. But the core philosophy? Still buying wonderful companies at fair prices.
HostB: And holding forever, or at least seeming like it.
